Detailed Description

Error handling as a stand-alone or for classes vis inheritance.

Description

CMError has two main purposes. First is to have a throwing and reporting error interface that allows error tracking and debugging to be consistent between classes. And secondly, allows the PHP coder to adjust the level of error control real-time.

Inheritance and the Global Stack

PHP constructors for parent classes are not implicitly called, this means any class that inherits from CMError will have to remember to invoke parent::__construct(). The work around for this is to have the methods check CMError::$GlobalStack at runtime. Which means changing CMError::$GlobalStack will affect ALL objects created at any point in time before or after the change.

Author:
Elliot Chance
Since:
1.0

Member Function Documentation

countErrors ( $  level = CMErrorType::Warning  ) 

Count the number of errors on the stack.

Parameters:
$level The minimum level to count as an error, by default this is 'Warning'.
Returns:
The number of items on the stack, this will always be an integer that has a value greater than or equal to 0.

Definition at line 121 of file CMError.php.

dealtWithAll (  ) 

Clear the error stack.

When an error is dealt with it is removed from the stack. This will remove all errors from the stack.

Returns:
Always true.

Definition at line 148 of file CMError.php.

Get the stack of errors.

Parameters:
$level The minimum level to count as an error, by default this is 'Warning'.
Returns:
The errors for this instance stack.

isErrors ( $  level = CMErrorType::Warning  ) 

Check if an error has occured.

This is just a quick way of finding out if an error occured.

Parameters:
$level The minimum level to count as an error, by default this is 'Warning'.
Returns:
true or false.

Definition at line 96 of file CMError.php.

printAllErrors (  ) 

Print all the errors on this stack.

This is the equivilent to invoking CMError::PrintError() on each error on this stack.

Returns:
Always false.

Definition at line 456 of file CMError.php.

static PrintBackTrace ( $  error  )  [static]

Print a backtrace of an error. 

 if($e->isErrors()) {
   echo "There were ", $e->countErrors(), " errors:\n";
   foreach($e->errors() as $error)
    CMError::PrintBackTrace($error);
 }
Parameters:
$error The error object.

Print an error. 

 if($e->isErrors()) {
   echo "There were ", $e->countErrors(), " errors:\n";
   foreach($e->errors() as $error)
    CMError::PrintError($error);
 }
Parameters:
$error The error object.

Definition at line 208 of file CMError.php.

setExitLevel ( $  exitLevel = CMErrorType::Fatal  ) 

How serious the error has to be to force exit the script.

By default this is CMErrorType::Fatal and only applies to this error stack (not global)

Parameters:
$exitLevel Must be a value from CMErrorType.
Returns:
Always true.

Definition at line 60 of file CMError.php.

static SetGlobalStack ( $  newStack  )  [static]

Set the global stack.

Any objects created after the point of invoking this static method will inherit the supplied error stack and NOT use their own stack. You can pass null or false to turn the feature off.

Note:
In any case this only affects objects that are created after the point of invoking this static method.
Parameters:
$newStack Must be a CMError object.
Returns:
true on success, otherwise false.

Definition at line 428 of file CMError.php.

setVerboseLevel ( $  verboseLevel  ) 

Change the verbosity level.

By default a new CMError verbosity level will be CMErrorType::Warning. That means is an error is thrown that is Warning or higer seriousness it will be printed immediatly to the page.

Parameters:
$verboseLevel Must be a value from CMErrorType.
Returns:
Always true.

$  attr = array() 
)

Throw a Debug level message.

If no $toStack is provided then the $msg will be used.

Parameters:
$msg The message to print.
$attr The number, string, array or object to place on the error stack that will replace the $msg.
Returns:

Definition at line 351 of file CMError.php.

throwFatal ( $  msg,
$  attr = array() 
)

Print a message and force exit the script.

There is no need to pass a $toStack item as your wont be able to check it after the script exists. However it is there to remain consistant with the other throw methods.

Parameters:
$msg The message to print before exiting.
$attr Ignored.
Returns:
Always false.

Definition at line 295 of file CMError.php.

useErrorStack ( $  newStack  ) 

Redirect the errors to a different stack.

The current error stack will be replaced with the object for the new stack. That means if there are any errors currently on this stack they will be discarded.

To reset the error stack back to this instance, set $newStack to null or false. If the class is already using its own stack and you invoke this method, the stack will always be replaced with a blank stack.

Note:
When changing the stack remember that all the methods of this instance will use the external stack as its true error stack.
Parameters:
$newStack Must be a CMError object.
Returns:
true on success, otherwise false.

Definition at line 399 of file CMError.php.
